Comment: Not for nothing, but I'm always skeptical of articles that fail to cite the study they're talking about.  Neither this article, nor the newsweek article it links to, cite the study.  While I'm pretty sure this is true, I'm also pretty sure its deceptively true.  We've been seeing for a few years now a widening ideological gap between young men and young women.  I suspect the results being talking about in this article would indicate, if we were able to see the original study, that as an aggregate young people skew more conservative than progressive, but when broken down we will find that it is primarily young *men* who are skewing the results.  Why it matters?  Because losing half the young person voting bloc is not something to get complacent about due having been fed deceptively-edited information about how secure the young person voting bloc is.

Comment: I think that's part of it, but I think part of it is the death of legacy media. The political left dominated US Media for decades, but they got caught with their pants down as the media landscape shifted from the TV news of old to the age of Youtube and podcasts. And it came at them from two angles: first, conservatives actually had a meaningful voice in the media for the first time basically ever, but the other side of it is that in the realm of podcasts and political influencers, the left really *didn't* have a voice, not to the same extent that the right did.  The death of legacy (TV-based) media was inevitable as technology changed. This wasn't some 4D chess move by conservatives to intentionally alter the media landscape. People were never going to keep watching cable TV. The fact that the Democratic Party got so blindsided by this, especially after the success that Obama had in using the internet to appeal to young (millennial) voters is truly baffling.

Comment: I would argue that approval rating of a president does not = conservative principles necessarily. Especially when said president has a mix of both 90s democratic and 80s republican stances.  Gen X trended more areligious or agnostic than probably silent and baby boomers, and trends more towards the left than their parents.  The coalition that Trump has formed this time around has ex democrats in its ranks and is appealing to more sane takes of a bygone age that older democrats would be completely on board for (immigration and social issues). Therefore, approval rating isn’t really indicative of anything other than they like how Trump is currently running things.   How they raised their kids is a completely different story.  To say Gen X is *the most conservative* generation is giving them way too much credit. They, along with a large portion of millennials, have caused irreparable harm because a large portion of these two generations completely lost the plot when it comes to values. Not saying they were or are all bad, but they aren’t exact a shining example of conservative values.
